Award.AwardTitle: Facility Support of the WInSAR Archive for Crustal Dynamics Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
0733437
Meertens

This grant supports a three year effort to: 1) develop a multi-satellite synthetic aperture radar (SAR) data ordering, distribution and archiving system; 2) purchase new SAR scenes globally and over North America from the European, Canadian and Japanese Space Agencies; and 3) support development of open-source community software for SAR interferometry (InSAR). The U.S. still does not have a spaceborne SAR sensor and U.S. scientists are largely at the "mercy" of foreign providers for access to global SAR imagery in support of research on crustal deformation. InSAR offers a unique look at crustal deformation over large spatial extents (100s to 1000 km) and thus complements GPS observations. The technique has proven value for advancing understanding of volcanic, seismic and anthropogenic related (due to water and hydrocarbon resource extraction) crustal deformation. Locating a SAR scene data archive at the UNAVCO Facility is cost effective and borrows on existing data management personnel and hardware support of the UNAVCO Facility. The SAR data archive will ensure that U.S. scientists are afforded the opportunity to utilize spaceborne SAR images for a range of studies of societal relevance across the globe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many fields of Earth science involve the measurement of deformation or motion of the Earth’s surface to understand the processes going on beneath the surface. The Western North America InSAR (WInSAR) Consortium was started to enhance access for WInSAR members to synthetic aperture radar (SAR) data acquired by international satellites, while following the required data policies of the satellite data providers. Currently, no US satellite provides this type of data. This grant supported the operation of and improvements to the large WInSAR archive hosted at UNAVCO of SAR images from the European Space Agency and Canadian Space Agency covering many areas of the United States and adjacent parts of North America. In the last year, WInSAR has also started requesting acquisitions of SAR images over the WInSAR study sites with the new German SAR satellite called TerraSAR-X. The WInSAR archive access has been greatly improved in the last year with a new web user interface and applications programming interface (API) that enables much more efficient search and download of the SAR data.

The SAR images from the WInSAR archive can be combined using a technique called interferometry to measure the motion or dynamics of the ground surface between two or more image dates with a dense spacing between measurements and high precision. Typical spacing between measurements is between 5 and 100 m over areas that are 100 km wide or larger, with a measurement precision between 2 and 10 mm. This interferometric SAR (InSAR) technique has proven extremely effective for studying ground motion caused by a wide variety of different processes, both natural and anthropogenic. The WInSAR Consortium is a collective organization of universities, government laboratories and federal and state agencies that coordinates the interests of many scientists in different fields, and promotes the education of new scientists in InSAR and related techniques.  We concentrate primarily on geophysical investigation and modeling of crustal processes such as earthquakes and volcanoes, but consortium members have ongoing research in groundwater hydrology, cryospheric studies, vegetation science, and oceanography, as well as sponsoring research in as yet untested application areas.

The WInSAR archive and access through the web interface and API have been enabling scientists to develop new techniques that can extract ground motion from large amounts of SAR data. The WInSAR Consortium now has 76 US Full Member institutions and 33 Adjunct Member institutions from around the globe. WInSAR scientists have published 111 publications since the proposal for this work was written in 2007 using InSAR data or techniques. These peer-reviewed publications detail innovations in WInSAR analysis methods and their application to a wide range of Earth science problems. Results include studies of earthquakes to determine the faults that generated the earthquakes and measurement of strain building up on faults that could cause future earthquakes, studies of volcanic eruptions and monitoring of volcanoes for signs of future eruptions, measurement of ground subsidence due to groundwater extraction, and motion of glaciers and ice sheets.

The WInSAR Archive at UNAVCO is very successful in supporting the WInSAR science community and enabling both scientific research and improvements in the technology of SAR interferometric measurements of surface motion. Looking forward, we see exciting new science opportunities and ongoing growth of the InSAR and geodetic imaging community.
